NewWords.WordPhrase: n. wrong or excessive use; cruel treatment 滥用；虐待
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The World Health Organization (WHO) has published a report on drug abuse and addiction.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a particular way of considering an issue, etc. 角度，立场
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Seen from this angle the woman in the picture is smiling.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 讨厌的，恼人的  annoy vt. make angry, irritate; bother 使恼怒，使烦恼
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The annoying thing about the plan is that it's confusing.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 一套公寓房间；公寓
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. How many bedrooms do you have in your new apartment?

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 约会
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You can't see the president of the university unless you make an appointment.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. prepare or plan 安排
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Her marriage was arranged by her parents.

NewWords.WordPhrase: sometimes 有时
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She has been away form her home for about a year. At times she wishes she had never left.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a strong feeling of dislike 厌恶，反感
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Her aversion to alcohol caused her to avoid her friends' wedding party.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. having a bad temper 脾气坏的，易怒的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When his headaches developed, Nick became bad-tempered and even violent.

NewWords.WordPhrase: yet at the same time 但另一方面，然而
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He got turned down for a promotion, but then he never expected to get it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. （使）发咔哒声；用鼠标点击  n. 咔哒声
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When shopping online, you just click the mouse and order what you want to buy.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. with a short clear pronunciation 发音快而清脆的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The chief executive officer's clipped tones cracked over the telephone line.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  商业广告  a.  商业的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I hate commercials on television.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. 通信，交往
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some young people depend heavily on email to communicate with each other.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  连接
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. This town has very good road and railway connections with the coast.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. 相反地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You can add the fluid to the powder or, conversely, the powder to the fluid.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. 爬，爬行
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The wounded man crawled to the phone.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （犯）罪
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We need a positive program of crime prevention.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a person who judges or criticizes 评论家；对…持批评态度的人
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Art critics praised the young artist's work.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 提示， 暗示
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When he started to talk about the finances, that was our cue to get up and quietly leave.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  （datum 的复数形式）数据，资料
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. This data is stored on the network and can be accessed by anybody.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. persistently 顽强地， 坚持不懈地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She would fight doggedly for her rights as the children's mother.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. revise or correct 编辑
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Jack is busy editing Shakespeare's plays for use in schools.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 电子邮件  vt. 给…发电子邮件；用电子邮件发
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Young people like to keep in touch with their friends via email.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  感情上的；动感情的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She is grateful to him for his emotional support while she was in trouble.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  having or seeming to have no end 无休止的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The journey seemed endless.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (fled) v. run away (from) 逃走；逃离
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The customers fled from the bank when the alarm sounded.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  not stable, likely to change 不稳定的，可变的  n.  液体
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The situation is still fluid.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  体育馆， 健身房
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The basketball game was held in the gymnasium.

NewWords.WordPhrase: visible; likely to come soon 可看到的；临近
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It was early in the morning and there wasn't anyone in sight on campus.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  not able to feel, unsympathetic to other people's feelings 感觉迟钝的， 麻木不仁的   sensitive a.  敏感的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. My mother was a thinking woman, not an insensitive one.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  交往；相互作用  cyber-interaction n.  通过网络交往
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There is need for greater interaction among the different departments.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  互联网，因特网
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Whether we like it or not, the Internet is an ever-growing part of our lives.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. 理解；解释；（作）口译
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I would interpret his silence as a refusal.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.，vt. 接见； 面试
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The TV interview has been cancelled.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. too bad to be endured 不能忍受的，无法容忍的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The pain was so intolerable that I wished I was dead.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. 使感到不快，刺激（神经等）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You shouldn't have too many colors in a small space as the effect can jar.

NewWords.WordPhrase: learn about or be aware of (the news, etc.); move at the same rate as 及时了解或跟上
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Carrie likes to keep up with the latest fashions.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  笑，笑声
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. "Laughter is the best medicine" means that trying to be happy is a good way to fight worries.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. understand wrongly 错误地理解， 错误地解释
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The President's words had been misinterpreted.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 调制解调器
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He sent his work to the publishers by modem.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a terrifying dream 噩梦
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Tom didn't eat fish because it gives him nightmares.

NewWords.WordPhrase: connected to or controlled by a computer (network) 联机地，在线
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Our system is on line to the main computer.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 歌剧 （艺术）  soap opera 肥皂剧 （以家庭问题为题材的广播或电视连续剧）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is writing a book on Italian opera.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 口令，密码
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. No one could use the computer unless they had a password.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. imagine that others have (the same feelings, usu. unpleasant ones) as you 以为别人也有（与自己同样的情绪）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He projects his own thoughts and ideas onto her.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  关系
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. What is the relationship between language and thought?

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. depend confidently, put trust in 依靠，依赖
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Nowadays we rely increasingly on computers to control the flow of traffic.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 言辞，话语  v. 说，评说
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The principal of the school made some remarks about educational reform at the meeting.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. bring back to former condition 恢复
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The army has recently been brought in to restore order.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 例行事务，日常工作，惯例
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The job is really just a dull series of fairly routine tasks. I don't think you'll take it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 使分离，使分开
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. What sets it apart from hundreds of similar small French towns is the huge factory.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. mix socially with others 社交，交际
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It distressed her that she no longer socialized with old friends.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (spat or spit) vt. 吐出
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The baby spat its food out on the table.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. (cause to) become longer, wider, etc. without breaking 拉长, 伸展
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. My working day stretches from seven in the morning to eight at night.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. give (sth.) to sb. so that it may be formally considered 提交，呈递
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I am going to submit an application for that job in Microsoft.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v.  draw liquid or air into the mouth 吸，吮  suck in 吸引，使卷入；吸收
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I don't want to get sucked into the debate about school reform.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 自杀
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There were three suicides in one week.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 征兆；症状
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. High interest rates are a symptom of a weak economy.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 收进，吸收
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The earth takes in heat and light from the sun.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. one who works from home, communicating with the workplace using a computer terminal 远程工作者
n. 语气， 口气，腔调
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. From he tone of her voice I could tell she was very angry.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. T 恤衫
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. T-shirts usually have short sleeves.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 曲子，曲调
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She whistled a happy tune all the way home.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 内衣
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He went for a late-night swim in his underwear.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 失业
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was thrown into unemployment when the factory closed.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.虚拟的; 实质上的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I can visit a virtual store and put what I want in my basket at the click of a mouse button.
